translated: 15 Commentary on the Verses of the Abhidharma-koÅ›a, Treatise, Section 17ğŸ”½From here, the second major section explains the names and meanings of the paths of karma. The treatise says: Thus far...ğŸ”½

From here, the second major text explains the meaning of the name of the path of action. The treatise states: Thus, the characteristics of the ten paths of action have been explained. Based on what meaning is it called the path of action? The verse says:
Among them, three are only paths, seven are also actions and paths.
The commentary says:
Among them, three are only paths.
Among these ten paths of action,
greed and so forth are only paths.
Because they are the paths of action,
they are called paths of action.
It is said that volition associated with greed and so forth is called action.
Because volition arises due to the arising of greed and so forth.ğŸ”½Because volition moves due to the movement of greed and so forth.
Because volition has activity due to the power of greed and so forth.
Therefore, greed and so forth
are the paths for volition.
Seven are also paths because the previous seven are actions.
Because they are bodily and verbal actions.
They are also the paths of action.
Because they are the domain of volition.
Because the volition that gives rise to them arises based on body and speech.
The seven thoughts of body and speech are what is traversed.
They are also the path of karma.
The first seven are karma.ğŸ”½The path of karma.
Therefore, the name of the path of karma is established.
The upper karma is the karma of body and speech.
The lower karma is the thought that gives rise to it.
Therefore, it is called the karma of karma.
Therefore, the path of karma.
Fully reveals the meaning of the path of karma, the karma of karma.
Although they are not of the same type.
The name of the path of karma is the same.
But one karma is for the other karma.
One path is for the other path.
Just like the world, the name of the cart and ox is the same.
But one cart and ox is called the other cart and ox. In the classics.
Like the saying about the abode of consciousness.
Although there are four abodes of consciousness.
The nature and type are different.
The name of the abode of consciousness is the same, but one abode of consciousness is called the other abode of consciousness. Apart from the seven such as killing.
The three such as non-greed.
The name of the path of karma is established.
It should be explained according to the previous type.
From here, the third.
The meaning is convenient to clarify the severance of good.
The treatise says.
The above is explained.
These ten evil karmic paths
All contradict the arising of wholesome dharmas.
Those who sever the wholesome roots
By which karmic pathğŸ”½Do they sever the wholesome roots? How is the continuation of the wholesome roots
Distinguished?
The verse says:
Only wrong views sever the wholesome roots. Those severed are the wholesome roots obtained from birth in the desire realm.
One who denies cause and effect severs [the wholesome roots] gradually. Both [male and female] abandon [the wholesome roots] together.
Humans in the three continents, both male and female, sever [the wholesome roots] through views and practice. One who has not attained [the wholesome roots] severs [the wholesome roots].
One who continues the wholesome roots, one who has doubts, and one who has views [of annihilationism] suddenly manifest, excluding those who commit the heinous crimes.
The commentary says:
Only wrong views sever the wholesome roots.
Only the highest and most complete wrong views
Can sever the wholesome roots.
However, in the treatise
It is said that the three unwholesome roots of greed, hatred, and delusion
Can sever the wholesome roots.
This is because the unwholesome roots can lead to wrong views.
The severing by wrong views is attributed to those roots.
It is like a fire burning a village. The fire is started by thieves.
Therefore, the world says that the village is burned by thieves.
Those severed are the wholesome roots obtained from birth in the desire realm.
The severed wholesome roots
are only those of the desire realm.
They are the innate wholesome roots.
That is to say, when severing the wholesome roots,
the wholesome roots of the form and formless realms
have not yet been attained,
and therefore cannot be said to be severed.
Why is it that only the innate wholesome roots are severed?
The wholesome roots of application
have already been lost.
That is to say, when severing the wholesome roots,
in the stage of application
one loses the wholesome roots of application.
When it comes to the time of severing the wholesome roots,
one only severs the innate ones.
As for denying cause and effect in their entirety,ğŸ”½it clarifies the characteristics of wrong views.
Wrong views that deny cause
do not consider there to be good or evil conduct.
Wrong views that deny effect
do not consider there to be good or evil results.
In their entirety
refers to all wrong views.
All of them can sever wholesome roots.
That is to say, those that take one's own realm as object,
those that take other realms as object,ğŸ”½those that take contaminated objects as object,
and those that take uncontaminated objects as object.
Such wrong views
can all sever wholesome roots.
Other masters say:
Only those that take one's own realm as object.
And those that take contaminated [dharmas] as objects.
Only then can they sever wholesome [roots].
The others cannot sever them.
In order to counter them,
It is said that [the severing of wholesome roots] is done by all [three poisons].ğŸ”½As for the gradual severing [of wholesome roots],
It clarifies that the severing of wholesome roots is done gradually, not suddenly.
That is to say, there are nine grades of wrong views.
Severing the wholesome roots in nine grades.
Severing [wholesome roots] in the order of superior, medium, and inferior, and in the reverse order.
The first, the inferior of the inferior grade of wrong views,
Can sever the superior of the superior grade of wholesome roots.
Up to the superior of the superior grade of wrong views,
Can sever the inferior of the inferior grade of wholesome roots.
The wholesome roots, from the superior grade
To the inferior grade, are called in the reverse order.
Wrong views, from the inferior to the superior, are called in the forward order.
As for both are abandoned,
The two refer to the wholesome roots
And the precepts.
When severing the wholesome roots,
Both are abandoned simultaneously.
The treatise says:
If those precepts
Are the result that arises simultaneously with the mind of that grade,
When the mind of that grade is severed,
One abandons those precepts.
Because the result and the cause
The explanation says:
The nine grades of wholesome minds
Can each give rise to precepts.
Precepts are their fruits.
If one severs the lower grade of wholesome [minds],
One only abandons the lower grade of precepts.
Up to severing the upper grade of wholesome [minds],ğŸ”½One only abandons the upper grade of precepts.
The fruits of the various disciplines
Some arise from the preparatory stage,
Some are born from the wholesome mind. If they arise from the wholesome mind of the preparatory stage,
The disciplines are first abandoned.
Later one severs the wholesome roots. The explanation says:ğŸ”½The preparatory stage for severing the wholesome roots
Abandon the wholesome of the preparatory stage.
When abandoning the preparatory stage,
The wholesome roots of the preparatory stage
And the disciplines produced by them
Are abandoned at the same time.

Because they have no extreme evil intentions. This means intention.
Only male and female bodies.
Because their minds are determined.

Only those who see and practice.

All those who practice with affection.

Those who practice with views.

For this reason.

And this type of person.

And practice accordingly.
Those who practice with affection.
They simply believe the words of others.
And practice with affection.

It should be known that severing goodness.
Non-acquisition is its essence.
That is to say, when the wholesome [roots] are severed,
the wholesome [roots] do not arise.
Non-acquisition continues to arise.
The state in which non-acquisition arises,
is called the severance of the wholesome roots.
Therefore, the severance of the wholesome roots,
has non-acquisition as its essence.
As for the continuation of the wholesome [roots] by doubt and view,
doubt means doubting existence.
View means right view.
That is to say, in the midst of causes and effects, one gives rise to a mind that doubts existence.
This may or may not exist.
From a mind that doubts existence,
one may give rise to right view.
One definitely thinks that there is, not that there is not.
At that time, the acquisition of the wholesome roots continues to arise.
Therefore, it is called the continuation of the wholesome [roots].ğŸ”½The continuation of the wholesome [roots] by doubting existence,
and the severance of the wholesome [roots] by doubting non-existence.ğŸ”½In order to distinguish doubting non-existence,
it is said to be doubting existence.
As for suddenly manifesting and excluding the heinous [acts],
suddenly refers to the wholesome roots.
The nine grades are suddenly continued.
Then, at a later time,
they gradually manifest.
Like suddenly curing an illness,
one's energy gradually increases.
Manifest refers to the present world.
Those who continue goodness in their present bodies are those who have not committed the heinous crimes.
The sÅ«tra says that those who commit the heinous crimes
and those who sever goodness
definitely cannot continue goodness in their present bodies.
They definitely go to hell.
Only when about to die and about to be born
can they continue goodness.
After experiencing the results of hell,
it is called about to die.
In the intermediate state,
not yet born in hell,
it is called about to be born.
If, due to past causes,
wrong views cultivated in previous lives,
they sever goodness,
they can continue goodness when about to die.
If, due to the power of present evil teachings,
they sever goodness,
they can continue goodness when about to be born. One should understand it is also like this due to one's own and others' power. One's own means to investigate oneself.
Others means to encounter evil friends.
Moreover, if the love and joy is destroyed,
but not the practice,
this person can continue goodness in the present life.
If both are destroyed,
one can continue only after death.
Seeing that precepts are destroyed but not destroyed.
Also, continuing goodness in the present world.
Both precepts and views are completely destroyed.
It is necessary to continue goodness after death, and the appearance and protection of the precepts.
Is called the precepts are not destroyed.
There are those who sever the roots of goodness.
Not falling into wrong views.
Four alternatives should be made.
The first alternative is.

that are explained
among the two paths of action,

The verse says:
The paths of action turn together with intention, from one to eight in the unwholesome,
In the wholesome, generally up to ten, specifically blocked at one, eight, and five.
The commentary says:
The paths of action turn together with intention.
This is the heading.
Intention refers to the intention that arises in a moment.
This clarifies that the paths of action and the intention that gives rise to them

Greed, anger, and wrong viewsğŸ”½necessarily do not arise together.

and it occurs together with intention.
The second is:
It refers to the preliminary stage,
such as sending someone else to kill.
It refers to the creation of the six evil karmic paths.
When the mind is not defiled,
among the previous six,
one is completed.
A good or indeterminate mind
is called undefiled.
A defiled mind is completed
and forms the two that occur together.
Therefore it is said to be undefiled.
It refers to distinguishing the defiled mind that forms the two that occur together. The two that occur together refer to
using a mind of hatred
to complete the karmic path of killing.
If one gives rise to greed,
one completes the karmic path of taking what is not given.
Or if one gives rise to greed,
one completes the karmic path of sexual misconduct.
Sometimes one gives rise to greed and completes the karmic path of frivolous speech.
The above four categories
are called the two karmic paths.
They occur together with intention. The three that occur together refer to
using a mind of hatredğŸ”½to steal from another person,
taking it away from its original place,
and cutting off its life.
At the same time, one kills and steals.
The three of hatred, killing, and stealing.
and occur together with intention.
Moreover, in the preparatory stage,

Greed, ill-will, and wrong views,
when one is in the process of committing them,
with regard to the previously committed killing and so on,
two of them are completed.
Since greed and so on are one,
and killing and so on are two,
therefore three occur together.
As for four occurring together,
there are three types. The first four are:
Namely, wishing to destroy others,
one speaks false speech.
The mental karmic path is one,
and the verbal karmic paths are three.
Because of destroying others,ğŸ”½it is divisive speech. Because of speaking falsely,ğŸ”½it also becomes false speech. This is defiled speech,
which necessarily includes mixed and defiled speech.
Therefore the verbal karmic paths are three. The second four are:

one speaks harsh words.
The mental karmic path is one,

Because of destroying others,
it is divisive speech. Because of speaking harshly,
And again, coarse speech - this is defiled speech.
It must be mixed with foul language.
Therefore, the three of verbal action - the third set of four is as follows.
If one first formulates an intention,
and sends someone to kill, etc.,
committing an unwholesome physical action,
and greed, etc. are manifest,
with regard to the killing, etc. that have already occurred,
following through with any three of them to completion.
Since greed, etc. are one,

As for five occurring together,

As for six occurring together,
greed, etc. are manifest,

As for seven occurring together,

This should be understood according to the above.
As for eight occurring together,

The good and evil karmic paths.

From here, the sixth [chapter]
clarifies the three fruits of the karmic paths.
The treatise states:
What are the fruits obtained by unwholesome and wholesome karmic paths?
The verse says:
All can attract the fruits of retribution, equal flow, and predominance
Because they cause others to suffer, end life, and destroy dignity
The commentary says:
The first two lines generally clarify the three realms.
The last two lines specifically explain the reasons.
The ten evil karmic paths all attract the three fruits of retribution, equal flow, and predominance.
From here, one ends one's life and is born in the hells.
This is the fruit of retribution.
Coming to be reborn among humans,
one experiences the fruit of equal flow.
That is to say, one who kills has a short lifespan.
One who takes what is not given
Lacking in wealth and property.
For those who engage in sexual misconduct,
their wives are not chaste.
Due to false speech,
one encounters much slander.
For those who engage in divisive speech,
close friends become estranged.
For those who engage in harsh speech,
one constantly hears unpleasant sounds.
Due to frivolous speech,
one's words lack authority.ğŸ”½For the greedy, greed increases.
For the hateful, hatred increases.
For those with wrong views, delusion increases.
As for the dominant effects,ğŸ”½due to killing,ğŸ”½the resources one possesses have little luster.
Due to stealing,
one encounters much frost and hail.
Due to sexual misconduct,
there is much dust and dirt.
Due to false speech,
there are many foul odors.
Due to divisive speech,
the place one dwells is dangerous and treacherous.
Due to harsh speech,
the fields have many thorns, are barren, salty, and bitter.
Due to frivolous speech,
the seasons change unpredictably.ğŸ”½Due to greed, the fruits are few.
Due to hatred, the fruits are spicy.
Because of wrong views, the fruit is small.
Or it may be non-existent.
Question: What is the reason that each of these ten
each attracts three fruits?
Answer: This causes others to suffer,
to lose their lives, and to lose their dignity.
Therefore, first, killing living beings,
causes others to suffer,
and one receives the retribution fruit.
Because one ends the lives of others,
one receives the equal flow fruit.
Because one causes others to lose their dignity,
one receives the dominant fruit.
The other evil karmic paths
should be considered in the same way.
By this, one can understand
the three fruits of good karma.
Away from killing living beings, etc.,
one is born in the heavens.
One receives the retribution fruit.
Coming to be reborn in the human realm,
one receives the equal flow fruit.
That is to say, those who are away from killing
attain a long life.
The rest are the opposite of this,
and should be explained in the same way.
From here, the eleventh major section
specifically clarifies wrong livelihood.
The treatise says:
Moreover, the sutras say:
Among the eight branches of wrong practice,
form karma is divided into three.
Namely, wrong speech, wrong action, and wrong livelihood.
[One] is free from wrong speech and wrong action.
What is wrong livelihood?
Although [one] is free from those,ğŸ”½but [the Buddha] separately explains them.
The verse says:
Bodily and verbal actions born from greed are called wrong livelihood, because they are difficult to eliminate.
To hold that the means of livelihood is born from greed for life is unreasonable, because it contradicts the sutras.
The commentary says:
Verbal actions born from anger and delusion are called wrong speech.
Bodily actions born from anger and delusion are called wrong action.
Those born from greed,
the two bodily and verbal actions,
because they are difficult to eliminate,
are separately established as wrong livelihood.
That is to say, greed can steal the minds of sentient beings.
The actions produced by that,
are difficult to rescue and protect.
In order to earnestly cultivate the correct,
the Buddha separately explained it as one, apart from the previous [two].
As there is a verse that says:
In the world, wrong views are difficult to eliminate. Worldly people
always hold different views.
In the Way, wrong livelihood is difficult to protect. Those who have left the household life in the Way
because their necessities depend on others. To hold that the means of livelihood is born from greed for life means:
There are other masters who hold the view.
Taking life and material goods as objects,
and the greed that gives rise to bodily and verbal actions,
is called wrong livelihood.
Not all greed is called wrong livelihood.
Although play, enjoyment, and singing arise from greed,
because they do not sustain life, they are not wrong livelihood. The reason why this is unreasonable is because it contradicts the sÅ«tras.
This refutes the explanations of other masters.
This explanation contradicts the sÅ«tras.
In the Aggregate of Morality SÅ«tra,
observing elephant fights, etc.,
the World-Honored One also established [them] in the midst of wrong livelihood.
Wrongly receiving external objects,
emptyly prolonging life,
therefore, based on this sÅ«tra text,
all that arises from greed is called wrong livelihood.
From here, the third major section of the text.
Miscellaneous explanations of various karmas.
Within this, it is divided into ten parts.
First, explaining the karmas that obtain results.
Second, explaining the fundamental karmas.
Third, explaining the causes of attraction and completion.
Fourth, explaining the three kinds of heavy hindrances.
Fifth, explaining the three periods of hindrances.
Sixth, explaining the characteristics of bodhisattvas.
Seventh, explaining giving, morality, and meditation.
8. Clarifying the three types of karma that accord with the three parts.
9. Clarifying the essence of writing, etc.
10. Clarifying the different names of various dharmas.
In the first, clarifying the attainment of karmic fruits, it is divided into six parts.
1. Generally clarifying the fruits of various karmas.
2. The fruits of the three natures in mutual relation.
3. The fruits of the three periods in mutual relation.
4. The fruits of the various stages in mutual relation.
5. Clarifying the fruits of the three learnings in mutual relation.
6. The fruits of the three severances in mutual relation.
First, generally clarifying the fruits of various karmas.
The treatise states:
As previously stated, there are five kinds of fruits.
Among them, which karmas have how many fruits?
The verse says:
Karmic actions on the path of severing [afflictions] with outflows have five fruits in full.
Karmic actions without outflows have four, namely, excluding the matured fruit.
The remaining wholesome and unwholesome karmas with outflows also have four, excluding the fruit of separation.
The remaining karmas without outflows and indeterminate karmas have three, excluding what was previously excluded.
The commentary says:
The path of severing [afflictions] refers to
the various uninterrupted paths.
Because the uninterrupted path can realize the unconditioned severance.
And it is able to eliminate afflictions.
It is called the path of elimination.
This path is of two kinds.
It is both contaminated and uncontaminated.
Contaminated karma is fully endowed with five fruits.
In the previous path of elimination,
if there is contaminated karma,
it is fully endowed with five fruits.
Since it is contaminated,
it can attract the desirable karmic maturation of its own realm. The fruit of equal flow
refers to the similar dharmasğŸ”½in one's own realm that are equal or superior.ğŸ”½The fruit of disjunction
is the unconditioned liberation realized through eliminating afflictions. The fruit of the dominant conditionğŸ”½refers to the dominant condition of the path.
That is to say, the dominant condition of the path
immediately following the path of liberation.
That is to say, the future merits cultivated by the path.
The dominant condition of separation
refers to the unconditioned liberation realized by the path.ğŸ”½The dominant condition of non-arising
refers to the unconditioned liberation of elimination. The fruit of the dominant condition
refers to the conditioned dharmas other than one's own nature.
Only excluding the previously arisen.
There are four for pure karma, namely, excluding only the ripening.
On the path of severing that was previously explained.
If it is pure karma.
It is fully endowed with four fruits.
Because the pure does not attract fruits.
Only excluding the ripening.
The remaining contaminated good and evil also have four, excluding the fruit of separation.
Different from the path of severing before.
Therefore it is said to be the remaining.
The remaining contaminated.
If good or evil.
Also have four fruits.
Because it is not the path of severing.
Excluding the fruit of separation.
The remaining pure and neutral have three, excluding what was previously excluded.
Excluding what was previously severed.
The remaining pure.
And indeterminate dharmas.
Only have three fruits.ğŸ”½Excluding the ripening and separation that were previously excluded.
Because the pure and indeterminate.
Do not attract fruits.ğŸ”½Excluding the fruit of ripening.
Not being the path of severing.
Excluding the fruit of separation.
From here, second.
The three natures are opposed to each other in terms of fruits.
The treatise states:
Having already generally distinguished that all actions have results,
Next, the different aspects are discussed.
There is action that has results.

Good, etc. with respect to good, etc. - the first has four, two, and three;

Good, etc. with respect to good, etc.

The first refers to good actions.

Excluding the result of karmic maturation.

predominant.
It is drawn out by good causes.

Excluding the similar and the unconditioned.

Unwholesome karma.

Speaking of three effects.

Speaking of four effects.
Only excluding the effect of disjunction.

And the remaining unwholesome karma to be eliminated by seeing suffering.
As homogeneous causes.
Because the views of self and extremes are obscured and indeterminate.

Because it is after the wholesome and unwholesome. This indeterminate karma.

As its three fruits.

Clarifies the fruits of the three time periods.
The treatise states:
Having already distinguished the three natures,
next we will distinguish the three times. The verse says:
The past has four fruits for each of the three, the present and future are also like this.
The present has two fruits for the present, the future has three fruits for the future.
The commentary says:
This uses the three times of karma
to match the dharmas of the three times
to distinguish the differences in fruits.
These three times of karma
are partially embodied by the two aggregates of form and volition.
If the dharmas of the three times
are embodied by the five aggregates.
The past has four fruits for each of the three means
that past karma
uses the dharmas of the three times
to have four fruits for each,
only excluding the fruit of disconnection.
The present and future are also like this means
that present karma
also uses future dharmas
to have only four fruits,
the same as the past.
Therefore it says also like this.
The present has two fruits for the present means
that present karma
uses present dharmas
to have two fruits,

and the effect of human effort.
As for the three effects of future on future,
it refers to future karma.
Because future dharmas
only have three effects.
Excluding the homogeneous and the unconditioned.
It is not said that later karma has earlier effects.
Because earlier dharmas are definitely not the effects of later karma.
From here, the fourth.
Clarifying the effects of the various stages.

This is based on the karma of the various stages.

The distinctions in effects
Should be understood. The karma of the various stages
Only consists of a small part of the form and mental formations aggregates.

The same stage has four effects means

If it is uncontaminated karma,
it takes dharmas of different realms as its three fruits.
In addition to the first two fruits,
it also adds the similar fruit.
Because it does not fall into the realms,

From here, the fifth point is
to clarify the three fruits of the learner, etc.

Adept karma.

Non-learner and non-non-learner dharmas have two, two, and five effects.
That is, non-learner dharmas.
Taking learner dharmas as two effects.
Namely, the effect of human effort and the dominant effect. Taking non-learner dharmas as two effects.
Namely, the effect of human effort and the dominant effect. Taking non-learner and non-non-learner dharmas as five effects.
From here, the sixth.
Clarifying the three effects of the three such as the eliminated by insight.
The treatise states:
Having explained the learners, etc.,
Next, the eliminated by insight, etc. The verse says:
The eliminated by insight karma, etc., each has three in the three.
The first has three, four, and one; the middle has two, four, and three effects.

This takes the three eliminated karmas.

As the distinctions of effects.

All should be understood in order means:
According to their respective correspondences, they are all in the above six categories.
The causes and effects that are matched are all in order.
The explanation of only placing it at the end:
The concise Dharma should be like this.
From here is the second part of the main text.
Explaining the karma of the treatise.
The treatise states:
Having discussed the various karmas,
one should further ask:
As for the three karmas explained in the treatise,
namely, the karma that should be done,ğŸ”½the karma that should not be done,
the karma that is neither to be done nor not to be done,
what are their characteristics?
The verse states:
Defiled karma should not be done. Some say it also violates the rules.
The karma that should be done is the opposite of this. The third is the opposite of both.
The commentary states:
As for defiled karma should not be done,
some say the three defiled karmas
are called should not be done.
Because they arise from improper attention.
As for some say it also violates the rules,
Some other masters say:
It is not only defiled karma that is called improper.ğŸ”½Violating the rules of deportment is also called improper.
Violating the rules of deportment is indeterminate karma.
One should act and abide in this way.
One should wear and eat in this way.
If one does not act in this way,
it is called improper.
Because it violates propriety.
Proper karma is the opposite of this.
The opposite of improper is called proper karma.
Some say that good karma
is called proper.
Other masters say:
Karma that accords with the rules of deportment
is also called proper.
The third is the opposite of both.
It is the opposite of the first two.
It is called neither proper nor improper.
If one follows the first explanation,
it is only indeterminate karma.
If one follows the second master's explanation,
except for the rules of deportment,
the rest are indeterminate.
From here, the third point is
to clarify the causes of attraction and completion.
Within this, it is divided into two parts.
The first clarifies the amount of karma that attracts and completes.
Second, clarifying the essence of the causes of attraction and completion.
First, clarifying the number of karmas that give rise to [rebirth].
The treatise states:
Is it that a single karma only attracts a single lifetime?
Or does it attract many lifetimes?
Also, is a single lifetime only attracted by a single karma?
Or is it attracted by many karmas?
The verse states:
A single karma attracts a single lifetime. Many karmas are able to perfect it.
The commentary states:
A single karma attracts a single lifetime.
This explains the karma of attraction.
The old translation calls it the karma of general retribution.
According to the SarvÄstivÄda school,
it is only due to a single karma.
It only attracts a single lifetime.
If it is allowed that a single karma is able to attract many lifetimes,
the karma determined by time should become mixed up.
If this single lifetime
is attracted by many karmas,
it should be the case that the homogeneous character of sentient beings is divided into different parts.
This is because the fruits of karma are different, so they are divided into different parts.
This means dying and being reborn many times. Therefore, it should be known that a single karma
only attracts a single lifetime.
Many karmas are able to perfect it.
Explaining the full karma. The old translation says it is the karma of separate retribution.
It refers to the body in one lifetime.
Perfectly complete and adorned.
Allowing for many karmas.
It is like a painter first using one color to sketch the form.
Later filling in the many colors.
The use of one color to sketch the form.
Is analogous to the one karma that leads.
The later filling in of the many colors.
Is analogous to the many karmas that are defiled.
Therefore, although there are those who receive a human body,
Among them there are those who are endowed with complete limbs, body, complexion, strength, and adornments.
Or there are those who are deficient.
From here is the second.
Explaining the essence of the leading and completing causes.
The treatise says:
It is not only the power of karma that can lead and complete.
All wholesome, unwholesome,
and contaminated dharmas are all able to lead and complete.
Because karma is superior,
it is simply labeled with the name of karma. However, among them,
those that exist together with karmağŸ”½are able to lead and complete. If they do not exist together with karma,
they are able to complete but not lead,
because their power is inferior.
What is the nature of this kind?
Verse:
The two mindless concentrations obtain, but cannot attract the others.
Explanation:
The two mindless concentrations obtain means
The two mindless concentrations refer to
The attainment of non-perception and the attainment of cessation.
This is not simultaneous with the various karmas,
So it is not the attracting cause.
It can only be the fulfilling cause.
Obtaining refers to obtaining good and evil.
Obtaining is not the same fruit as the various karmas,
So it is only fulfilling, not attracting.
Apart from these two categories,
The remaining good and evil
All attract and fulfill.
From here, the fourth,
Clarifies the three obstacles.
Within this, there are two.
First, clarifying the three obstacles.
Second, specifically clarifying the obstacle of karma.
Within clarifying the three obstacles, there are two.
First, clarifying the essence of the obstacles.
Second, distinguishing them based on locations.
First, clarifying the essence of the obstacles.
The treatise says:
The BhagavÄn said:
The heavy obstacles are three:
Namely, the karmic hindrances.ğŸ”½Afflictive hindrances.
Retribution hindrances.
What are the natures of these three hindrances?
Verse:ğŸ”½The three hindrances are the uninterrupted karmas,
And the frequently occurring afflictions,
As well as all evil destinies, the northern continent, and the heaven of non-perception.
Explanation:
Three hindrances is the heading.
Uninterrupted karmas
Explains the essence of the karmic hindrances.
It refers to the five uninterrupted karmas,
Which are called karmic hindrances.
One, killing one's mother.
Two, killing one's father.
Three, killing an arhat.
Four, disrupting the harmonious Sangha.
Five, drawing blood from a Buddha.ğŸ”½And the frequently occurring afflictions
Explains the essence of the afflictive hindrances.
Afflictions are of two kinds:
One, frequently occurring,
Referring to afflictions that constantly arise,
Permeating the upper and lower grades.
Two, intense,
Referring to the upper grade of afflictions.ğŸ”½Only in terms of frequently occurring afflictions
Are they considered afflictive hindrances.
The upper grade of afflictions,
Which are not frequently occurring,
Although they are intense, they do not arise constantly.
They are easy to subdue and eliminate.
They are not said to be hindrances.
The lower grade afflictions,
although not intense,
if frequently practiced,
are difficult to eliminate.
Therefore, they are said to be hindrances.
Within the afflictions, whether superior or inferior,
but those that are frequently practiced,
are called the affliction hindrances.
All the evil destinies,
the northern continent, and the heaven of non-perception,
are the essence of the hindrance of retribution.
The three evil destinies,
the northern continent, and the heaven of non-perception,
are the hindrance of retribution. The question is: What does this hindrance obstruct?
The answer is: It obstructs the noble path and the practice of the noble path.
The practice of the seven skillful means.
The treatise says:
Among these three hindrances,
the afflictions and karma,
the two hindrances are both heavy.
Because if one has them, even in the second life,
one cannot be cured. The commentary says: Even in the second life,
one does not attain the path.
It is called incurable.
Moreover, the treatise says:
The VaibhÄá¹£ika masters give the following explanation:
Because the former can lead to the latter,
the latter is lighter than the former. It is explained that:
Afflictions lead to karma,ğŸ”½and karma leads to the ripening of karmic results. In terms of the ripening fruit,
there is no other karma or other birth
that can serve as an obstruction in between.
Therefore, it is called uninterrupted.
Or, having committed this karma,
one will definitely fall into hell.
There is no obstruction in between,
so it is called uninterrupted.
From here, the second part.
In terms of the realms, the treatise says:
It should be known that the three obstacles
exist in which destinies?
The verse says:
Uninterrupted [karma] exists in the three continents, not in others, nor in eunuchs, etc.
They have little kindness and little shame. The other obstacles are common to the five destinies.
The commentary says:
Uninterrupted [karma] exists in the three continents, not in others, nor in eunuchs, etc.
Excluding Uttarakuru,
in the three continents,
only women and men
can commit uninterrupted [karma].
Not others, such as eunuchs, etc.
Those with little gratitude and little shame.
Explaining the eunuch and so on.
Even if they kill their parents, they do not have the uninterrupted karma.
This is because their parents have little kindness towards them.
Because they have little affection.ğŸ”½They have little shame and remorse
Towards their parents.
Because they have no heavy kindness.
Therefore there is no uninterrupted [karma].
By this principle,
Even if ghosts and animals harm their parents,
They also have no uninterrupted [karma].
Moreover, the Venerable One says:
Among the animal class,
If one has clear awareness,
One can also commit the uninterrupted [karma].
Like a wise horse.
Once there was a horse.
People coveted its breed.
They made it mate with its mother.
It realized it was its mother.
It was ashamed and died.
Moreover, if a person harms the parents of non-humans,
They do not commit the crime of immediate retribution.
Because the mind and object are inferior. This is based on humans being born from non-humans. The other hindrances are common to the five destinies.ğŸ”½The other afflictive hindrances,
And the hindrances of retribution,
It is found in all five destinies.
However, the karmic retribution obstacles,
among the human destinies,
only exist in the Northern Continent.
Among the heavenly destinies, only the Heaven of Non-perception.
